Body: Coastal areas are among the most popular places to live. Even though the development of the Gulf Coast can boost economic growth, the high density of people and industry is a threat to  the region’s environment.
Environment:
Reduces open space, increases erosion and reduces habitat for coastal wildlife.

Increases demand on environmental resources and creates more pollution.
Economy:
Increases construction-related jobs and leads to improved regional
infrastructure.

Increases tax
revenues from additional population.
Energy:
Additional housing and people use more energy.

Residential buildings - particularly single-family homes – makes maintenance more costly for energy companies.

Body: As the population increases, wastewater treatment becomes more important. Eco-friendly sewage treatment reuses the water and sludge by-products and harvests the inherent energy in sewage.
Environment:
Creates less pollution through green, efficient sewage treatment.

Constructing wetlands for wastewater treatment can create productive habitat.
Economy:
Construction costs for environmentally sound, high-efficiency sewage treatment are higher.

Over time, high-efficiency plants save money in operating costs.
Energy:
Environmental, high- efficiency sewage treatment uses less energy, and, in some cases, none.

Methane generated from treatment plants can be used as alternative energy.

Body: Financial and information businesses offer higher paying positions and do not negatively impact the environment as much as manufacturing.
Environment:
More businesses and people place more demands on the resources of the region.

Non-manufacturing business is low polluting.
Economy:
Creates high paying jobs and improves the local economy.

Businesses increase tax revenues that, in turn, support more local infrastructure.
Energy: More people and more business means more energy consumption.

Body: Historically the Gulf Coast has been home to manufacturing industries such as paper mills, refineries, aerospace and defense.
Environment:
Manufacturing has been responsible for high levels of pollution.

More businesses and people place more demands on the resources of the region.
Economy:
Manufacturing creates jobs for large numbers of people.

Businesses increase tax revenues that, in turn, support more local infrastructure.
Energy: More people and more business means more energy consumption.

Body: Deepening existing shipping channels will allow larger ships access to the ports. Increasing port capacity means more goods can arrive more efficiently.
Environment:
Dredging can harm or destroy some habitats like seagrass beds and coral reefs.

More goods transported by larger ships could reduce the amount of pollution.
Economy:
Creates more business at the ports and along the coast.

Shipping is an efficient and inexpensive way to transport goods.
Energy:
Oil and gas are transported by ship, and larger ships mean more capacity.

More shipping activity, in general, would use more fuel.

Body: Raising catch limits for commercial and recreational fishing would expand both industries by allowing more fish to be caught. However, increasing the limits can endanger fish populations.
Environment:
Increased quotas can lead to overfishing, putting more species at risk.

Increased quotas may result in more fishing boats, causing more disruption to habitats.
Economy:
Raising the limits increases the volume of fish available to sell. 

Overfishing can cause a collapse in the industry when fish become scarce.
Energy: More fishing means more boats using more fuel.

Body: Fish farms are caged systems for producing fish. A sustainable aquaculture industry would increase the locally-grown seafood supply and provide new economic opportunities.
Environment:
Waste and pollution from  fish farms can lead to diseases among the wild fish in the Gulf.

Non-native fish can escape from farms and breed with or kill native species.
Economy:
Could disrupt local fishing communities because fish farms are often owned by large corporations.

Adds local jobs for processing fish.
Energy:
Fish farms are well-positioned to use alternative energy (wind, solar,  etc.).

Fish farms could rent vacant offshore oil platforms as staging areas.

Body: "Eco-travel” encourages tourists to enjoy the natural world in a socially responsible manner, promotes conservation, limits negative human impact, and supports the local population.
Environment:
Increases public awareness and appreciation for the environment.

Engages the tourist industry with low or no impact on the environment.
Economy:
Expands offerings of the tourism industry.

Helps rural communities attract more tourists.
Energy:
Service industry and tourists would use more fuel and energy.

Eco-tourism provides opportunity to explore alternative energy (wind, solar, etc.)
